oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Interview - Byron Gallimore - 2018-01-28
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Interview program titled Music Masters with Byron Gallimore from the Ford Theater at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum on January 28, 2018. Includes excerpts of recorded audio and audio from video.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Byron Gallimore;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Walk-In Music / (01:26) Opening announcements by Abi Tapia / (02:27) Walk-in music / (03:23) Opening comments and Byron Gallimore introduction by Michael McCall / (06:14) Opening comment by Byron / (06:33) Introduction of video with audio only / (07:02) Video screening of the song I Like It, I Love It by Tim McGraw / (08:31) Talk about the recording of the previous song / (12:53) Byron talks about his hometown, his family history and musical background / (17:06) Talks about his education and performing / (19:30) Talks about his band Commonwealth / (20:14) Talks about beginning to think about music as a career / (21:37) Beginning to write songs and thinking about a professional career in Nashville / (23:21) Moving to Nashville and working with Dick James Music / (23:44) Talks about Charley Pride and running Charley's publishing company / (26:06) Talk about why he began focusing on producing rather than song writing /

(27:03) Talks about meeting Tim McGraw and beginning to produce his recordings / (29:04) Record production history and working with Jo Dee Messina / (30:46) Talks about working with James Stroud / (33:28) Talks about Lyn Peterzell and Tim McGraw, and other artists he began working with / (35:31) Talks about feeling no pressure while recording McGraw's second album / (36:05) Talks about recording Indian Outlaw and recording his second album / (39:01) Talks about the song Don't Take The Girl and recording it with Tim McGraw / (40:31) Talks about the lyrical controversy of Indian Outlaw and radio play / (41:50) Talks about Tim's third album, their 55 top ten hits together and talks about his relationship with Tim / (45:16) Talks about the role he plays in the orchestration of Tim's recordings / (46:20) Talks about the guitar used on the recording Humble And Kind / (46:54) Talks about particular songs and specific arrangers they wanted to use / (48:47) Talks about Billy Sherrill /
